How your dairy is made.

2019 Summer

Html, Css, JavaScript

In a group of 2, we were asked to build a website that visualize information and data. The purpose of our website is to educate the public about the life cycle of a milk cow.

View the project.

Process

Challenges

When I first started on this project, one of the processes that took a while for me to become accustomed to was the iterative process. Previously, a project would typically have a first and second draft, and then you submit the final. For this one, the standard to this process usually worked its way to 5 – 10 versions before it would come close to nearing its final iteration. At first, I found it frustrating that there were tiny details I would personally be fine with, but would be picked out by my professor. I have come to love this process because it is these questions and nit-picking that made me recognize the potential and flaws in my work. By iterating, it only makes for a better final product.

Navigation

In order to organize our content, things such as the labels of each piece of content and how if fits within the website wireframe, are important. Good usability is always the priority. Rather than “Introduction” “About” etc., we want more descriptive labels like “Milk Production” “Milk Alternatives” to let our user know what to expect after clicking. We may use icons to enhance the visual.

Challenge

A design challenge would be finding a way of representing the data and information in a clear and concise way. In a way that would help the audience to understand the information easily, as a long and boring paragraph can often be hard to digest, and we can lose audiences.
Because using a giant block of words can lose audiences, instead, we used icons and infographics to help the reader quickly understand the information. Not only is this a good way to deliver the information, but it is also aesthetically pleasing.

EVALUATION

The most interesting thing about developing these pages were the organizational aspects of it. With the site theme that was in use, sometimes content blocks and pages were not entirely intuitive in terms of site-flow and its relationship to parent or child pages. This meant that a lot of code like CSS had be edited elsewhere, depending on where the page was situated in the site hierarchy. Thankfully, I have my Ta and Professor was able to jump in and guide me through obstacles I had. Discussing with my teamate, I learned how to offers various solutions to the single problem.
